Weiss (NYU Cinema Studies / NYU Performance Studies) Schedule 11:00 – 2:00 Gelsey Bell Seeing Sound: Three Generations of Sol Lewitt’s “Sentences on Conceptual Art” in Conversation with Tom Rojo Poller’s “The Tentative Ear” Alex Waterman Yes, But is it Edible?: Robert Ashley and the Impossible Landscape of Television Opera Sylvie Vitaglione Weight, Texture and the Sounds of Falling Bodies in Experimental Dance Films André Lepecki phonodermachoreography: dance’s clattering 2:00 – 3:30 Lunch 3:30 – 6:30 Richard Allen Sound, Matter, Spirit: Robert Gardner’s “Forest of Bliss” Ariane Lebot Music in Collaboration: Negotiating Meaning Through Sound Bill Simon Some Unanswered Questions About the Use of Pre-existing Classical Music in Film Scores Greg Zinman Experimental Media’s Sonic Challenge to the Index 6:30 – 7:30 Reception Bios Richard Allen is chair of the department of Cinema Studies at NYU. He is the author and editor of numerous books, including Projecting Illusion: Film Spectatorship and the Impression of Reality (Cambridge University Press, 1995); Hitchcock's Romantic Irony (Columbia University Press, 2007); Film Theory and Philosophy (Oxford University Press, 1997). His specialties include film theory and the philosophy of film, as examined in Projecting Illusion (Cambridge University Press, 1997) and the anthologies he edited, Film Theory and Philosophy (Oxford University Press, 1999) and Wittgenstein, Theory and the Arts (Routledge, 2001), co-edited with Malcolm Turvey. He has a special interest in the films of Alfred Hitchcock, which includes three Hitchcock anthologies and editorship of The Hitchcock Annual , as well as the book length study, Hitchcock's Romantic Irony (Columbia University Press, 2007). More recently, he has devoted a book to the poetics and aesthetics of Hindi cinema, Islamicate Cultures of Bombay Cinema (Tulika, 2009), and collaborated with Professor Ira Bhaskar on curating a film festival in Abu Dhabi and New York: Muslim Cultures of Bombay Cinema. Gelsey Bell is a singer, songwriter, and scholar. She has published articles in TDR, Movement Research Performance Journal, Tempo , and Women & Performance . She is an ABD doctoral candidate in Performance Studies at NYU, currently finishing a dissertation about American mid-twentieth-century experimental vocal music. As a vocalist and composer, she has several albums and has performed her work internationally. She is a core member of thingNY and Varispeed, and has worked with numerous artists in the creation of new work, including Robert Ashley, Matthew Barney, Jonathan Bepler, Kimberly Bartosik, Yasuko Yokoshi, Dave Malloy, Rachel Chavkin, Kate Soper, and John King, among others. She is also the Critical Acts coeditor for TDR . Ariane Lebot is PhD Candidate in Cinema Studies. She received her BA in Cinema and Audiovisual Studies and French Literature from Université de la Sorbonne Nouvelle – Paris 3 in 2009. She received a MA in Cinema Studies in 2012, for which her coursework specialized in archival studies and economy, and she wrote her thesis on “Bernard Herrmann's Contribution to Brian De Palma's Sisters and Obsession , and Larry Cohen’s It’s Alive ”. She also received a Master’s in Ethnology and Social Anthropology in 2012 for which she wrote her thesis on “Collections of objects and experiences” which focused on collectors of film reels and other cinematographic objects. Her research focuses on the relationship between music, sound and the image, as well as production studies. André Lepecki is Associate Professor at the Department of Performance Studies at NYU. His curatorial work includes: chief curator of the performing arts festival IN TRANSIT (2008 and 2009), Haus der Kulturen der Welt, Berlin and co-curator of the archive Dance and Visual Arts since 1960s, for MOVE, Hayward Gallery, London (2010). Selected Awards and Fellowships include AICA Award Best Performance (2008) for co-curating and directing the authorized re-doing of Allan Kaprow’s 18 Happenings in 6 Parts (Performa 07) and Resident Fellow Institute of Advanced Studies Interweaving Performance Cultures, Freie Universität, Berlin (2009). Visiting Professor Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (CAPES International Visiting Professor Grant, 2013). His book Exhausting Dance: performance and the politics of movement (2006) has been translated into 9 languages; and he has edited: Dance (2012), Planes of Composition: dance, theory and the global (2009, with Jenn Joy); The Senses in Performance (2007, with Sally Banes); and Of the Presence of the Body (2004). William Simon is the author of The Films of Jean Vigo (1981); guest editor of a special issue on Orson Welles, Persistence of Vision #7 ; and director of the retrospective exhibit and conference entitled, “Orson Welles: Theatre, Radio, Film.” His articles include: “Hitchcock: The Languages of Madness” in Alfred Hitchcock Reader (Wayne State University Press); “Welles, Bakhtin: Parody,” Quarterly Review of Film and Video ; “An Analysis of the Structure of The Godfather: Part One,” Cinematic Text: Methods and Approaches (AMS Press, 1989); “Karina and Godard,” in a catalog published by Art Institute of Chicago; “An Approach to Point of View,” Film Reader 3 ; “A Completely Open Space: Michael Snow’s La Region Central,” Millennium Film Journal ; “Taris,” Artforum ; “Tom, Tom, the Piper’s Son,” Artforum . Sylvie Vitaglione is a PhD student in the Department of Cinema Studies at NYU. She received a BA from University of California Berkeley in Dance/Performance Studies and Italian Studies in 2009, and an MA in Film Studies from University College London in 2010. In addition, she attended Russian ballet school in the south of France and trained as a contemporary dancer in San Francisco and London. Her dissertation explores the role of landscape and urban space in experimental dance films from the 1960s to the present, from North America and Europe. Her research interests include theories of the body in movement in nature and the built environment, site-specificity, choreography and the moving image. Her next conference paper, “Experimental Dance Films and the Misuse of Urban Space,” will be presented in London, where in Autumn 2014 she will be a visiting scholar at NYU London. Alex Waterman is a founding member of the Plus Minus Ensemble and he performs with the Either/Or Ensemble. In 2007 he curated two exhibitions, one on experimental music and poetics: Agapê at the Miguel Abreu Gallery and Between Thought and Sound: Graphic Notation in Contemporary Music at The Kitchen. He directed (with Beatrice Gibson) and wrote the music for A Necessary Music , narrated by Robert Ashley, which premiered at the Whitney Museum ISP show and won the Tiger Prize for Best Short Film at the Rotterdam Film Festival in 2008. His writings have been published by Sternberg Press, Dot Dot Dot, Paregon, FoArm, Bomb , and Artforum , and he has shown work at Kadist (Paris), Vilma Gold (London), ICA (London), and Tanya Bonakdar (Chelsea). He is staging three operas by Robert Ashley in a “live television” studio for the 2014 Whitney Biennial. His dissertation is entitled Music is the Social Body Sounding , and his book on composer Robert Ashley is forthcoming. Gregory Zinman received his doctorate in Cinema Studies from NYU in 2012. He is currently an ACLS New Faculty Fellow in the Film Program at Columbia University; scholar-in-residence at the New York Filmmakers' Cooperative; and curatorial consultant to the Yale University Art Gallery for their forthcoming retrospective of light artist Thomas Wilfred. He curated “Computer Age,” a screening series at the Museum of the Moving Image exploring the experimental origins of digital cinema, and has written for The New Yorker, American Art, Film History, A New History of German Cinema, Animation Journal , and Millennium Film Journal . He has forthcoming essays in Special Effects: New Histories, Theories, Contexts; German Expressionism: Der Blaue Reiter and its Legacies ; and Abstract Video , and is currently finishing Handmade: The Moving Image in the Artisanal Mode , and co-editing with John Hanhardt Nam June Paik: The Collected Writings . This event is free and open to the public. NYU Cinema Studies Join our  Facebook  page! Study Abroad Summer High School Summer in New York City Programs for Visiting Students Open Arts Minors Blog Events Newsletters Videos Admin & Faculty Alumni Contact Us  home > Special Programs        Film Production: Sight and Sound    This program is a full-time, 12-18 unit program. The Kanbar Institute of Film and Television at Tisch School of the Arts educates students in the art, craft, and technology of ﬁlm, television, video, animation, and sound production. The program offers intensive, hands-on production experience coupled with a broad exposure to the liberal arts. Sight and Sound: Filmmaking 6 units Every student will conceive, produce, direct and edit five short projects (3 silent and 2 with sound) with digital filmmaking technology. Working in crews of four, students will be exposed to a variety of specific assignments in visual storytelling that feature a broad spectrum of technical, aesthetic, craft and logistical problems to be solved. Collaborating with other students through rotating crew positions will be a central focus of all production work. Lectures, labs, critiques, technical seminars, screenings and written production books will be an important component of this class. All student work is screened and discussed in class. Students should not schedule any other course on the same days as Sight & Sound: Filmmaking. Additional Courses: Visit the Spring at Tisch Companion Course page to learn how to select additional courses to complete your full-time Spring at Tisch program. After receiving your application, a member of our team will contact you to help you select your courses. If you have any questions about course options, please contact tisch.special.services@nyu.edu . A fundamental-level core production workshop introducing the world of sound in film, television, and radio. Students will explore through individual and group projects of increasing complexity and sophistication the art of creating a "theater of the mind" in the sound medium.    Laboratory periods are designed to provide a wide variety of audio recording experiences both on location and in studio. Specific production techniques such as live recording, mixing, and editing will be stressed.    Lectures will focus on the theories of basic acoustics and audio electronics, the aesthetics of the sound medium, and the development of critical listening skills.
